column5: message

Document deployment process

Closes #122 because this is our preferred method.

`font-display: swap` for FOPST instead of FOUT/FOIT

Despite lack of universal browser support, this CSS feature seems like
a useful way to lessen the effects of waiting for our custom font to
load. This avoids FOIT (flash of invisible text) and FOUT (flash of
unstyled text) by telling the browser to use the next available font
in our `font-family` stack until our preferred font is
downloaded. This should replace FOUT with what we might call
FOPST (flash of partially styled text).

I'm also leaving open the possibility of switching to `optional`, so
that users on slow connections are not forced to download our
preferred font. Further experimentation is necessary.

Merge pull request #126 from jez/jez-margin-bottom

Make 'h2'/'h3' margin consistent with 'p' margin

Make 'h2'/'h3' margin consistent with 'p' margin The margin-top and margin-bottom on a `

` tag is 1.4rem. When two `

` tags are adjacent to each other, the margin bottom of the first and the margin top of the second collapse together—they're only separated by 1.4rem total. On the other hand, the margin-bottom on `

` and `

` is 0. Normally this is fine, because of the time a `

` follows the heading, so the margin-top on the paragraph picks up the correct vertical spacing. The problem is when a heading isn't followed by a paragraph (let's say: a generic

). If that div doesn't set margin-top like paragraphs do, then both the heading and the div will be 0px apart. (In particular, if there are descenders in the heading, they'll overlap!) There are then two solutions: 1. Set a margin-bottom on the heading 2. Set a margin-top on the div Setting a margin-top on the div essentially adds a *special case* for the div. On the other hand, setting a margin-bottom solves the *general case* of "vertical spacing after a heading."

Merge pull request #121 from Saturate/feature/performance-fix

Optimize all images

Optimize all images

Optimized images losslessly for web, they could be scaled down as well, but I'm not sure if they are used in their full size, so this commit does not include that optimization.

Use margin instead of padding for lists

Using margin instead of padding is preferred for nested lists.

We also drop the padding from 0.5rem to 0.25rem.
For use cases where you want a lot of spacing between the list items,
you should be wrapping the contents of the list item in a paragraph tag.

Only restrict width for top-level paragraphs

Top-level paragraphs should take up a percentage of the surrounding
<section>. All other paragraphs, (for example, those nested inside a
list, in a sidenote, etc.) should have the default: 100%.
Consistent line height in lists & paragraphs

Fix blockquotes. Fix small-viewport centering.

Tufte-style blockquotes do not have a right margin. On small screens,
content was shifted too much to the right and had excessive
margins. Media queries were unnecessarily split into two.

Shrink font size in pre-formatted code blocks

Smaller font in code blocks decreases the incidence of horizontal text
overflow, helps differentiate code from body text, and does not seem to
harm readability.

A possible fix to issue #92

Really just experimenting, so someone who knows what they're talking about should look at this.

Reduce font size and provide new fullwidth class for code.

Wrapping with pure CSS looks like a no go [1].  It is possible to do with
Javascript, but it gets complex to do right; for example, rewrapping long lines
on browser resize.

So, take solution from @Norgat in edwardtufte/tufte-css#80 and bump the font
down to 1rem.  This gives you:

    100 characters @ body width of 1040px
     80 @ 828px
     73 @ 750px (css break)

Seems like the best we can do.

Note that stackoverflow takes the same approach with code snippets; there is no
wrapping and you have to scroll horizontally.  So this UX is what most coders
are used to on the web.

It's kind of funny that neither Microsoft's [2], Google's [3] or iOS [4] style
guides mention showing code as text!

[1] http://stackoverflow.com/a/3750513
[2] https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/uwp/controls-and-patterns/fonts
[3] https://material.google.com/style/typography.html#
[4] https://developer.apple.com/library/ios/documentation/UserExperience/Conceptual/MobileHIG/ColorImagesText.html#//apple_ref/doc/uid/TP40006556-CH58-SW1

Provides a `booktabs` class for styling tables.

The booktabs package <http://ctan.org/pkg/booktabs> provides nice rules
and spacing for tables. Tables of this style are frequently used in
academic journals.

A heavy rule is used at the top and bottom of the table.
A medium-weight rule is separates the head row from the table contents.

Merge pull request #25 from jameskolce/master

Fix the use of sidenotes

Change name of sidenotes

Since `.sidenote-number` no longer contains only a number but a fragment
of text, we change the name to `.sidenote` and `.sidenote` to
`.sidenote-content`.

Fix the use of sidenotes

Span elements aren't self-closed tags in HTML5 (only in XHTML).
The symbol `/` is omited in HTML5, so `<span/>` is the same as `<span>`
The browser will find a way to close those tags somewhere and that's not
something we want.

To fix this we close the tags properly and to avoid empty elements we
wrap the relevant fragment of the text (see code).

By default `.sidenote-number` adds a number `before` the element, this work
only before the changes, so `:before` is replaced with `:after` to have
the desired result.
